parts.title: Bali's Emerging Architectural Identity
parts.body: Bali is evolving! Once referred to as a tropical paradise, the island is seeing changes with urbanization taking over areas like Denpasar and Seminyak. Despite this, there are still places where you can experience serenity and the island's classic beauty. Architectural trends are shifting towards modern styles with influences beyond traditional Balinese elements. The island now attracts those desiring modernity mixed with tropical charm—whether it's sleek private villas or creative, beautiful buildings. Even with this shift, Bali manages to preserve its natural surroundings in new structures, showcasing the essence of contemporary tropical living.

parts.title: Serene Balinese Villas: Emerald Sunset & River
parts.body: Two villas in Canggu highlight Balinese architecture and serene landscapes with views of rice fields. Both Emerald Sunset and Emerald River villas blend modern and traditional styles. Designed by Yoka Sara, the villas integrate old ironwood poles for structure and aesthetics. Emerald Sunset features three buildings with a unique metal roof, while Emerald River is more traditional, with buildings around a central "island" of trees. Both offer open living spaces, creating a relaxing holiday experience. The interiors showcase modern comfort amid lush gardens. Emerald Sunset includes a living area with a curved roof, while the bedroom building is complemented by a 20-meter pool. The villas feature elements like a dining pavilion, stone-tiled pool that changes colors, and breezy corridors with inclined wooden struts. Guests enjoy various lounging spots, including poolside terraces and open-plan living rooms overlooking gardens. These villas represent a perfect holiday oasis that mixes architecture with natural surroundings.

parts.title: Blending Homes with Landscape and Culture
parts.body:
Two Homes in Harmony with Nature

The first home was built in 2004 as guest quarters. Nestled between a road and a gorge, its design followed the land's natural shape. The architects aimed to make it blend seamlessly into the tropical landscape. Its standout feature is the curved roofs, resembling an upside-down boat keel, crafted to be pre-assembled and then reconstructed on-site in Bali. The home consists of two interconnected buildings with striking curved surfaces that flow with the land's contours. The organic materials such as wood and natural stone create an earthy feel, and the open-plan areas foster a light and breezy atmosphere, while blending with the surrounding vegetation. The second home is dominated by a striking steel framework roof, inspired by Frangipani tree branches. This frame covers a double-storey building, combining an open-air ground floor with enclosed upper levels, which offer seamless garden views. The master bedroom's unit, initially planned with a Frangipani motif, ended up being a simple glass-and-wood structure. This home exemplifies modern tropical design while respecting the local environment's cultural aspects.

parts.title: Serene Hillside Sanctuary
parts.body: The house is designed to appear as an extension of the surrounding rice terraces, with natural materials like stone and wood enhancing the feel. The main building features a mix of curved shingle roofs and flat stone volumes, making it look as though it blends into the landscape. Surrounded by a curving pool and lush landscaping, the house makes clever use of varying textures and colors to create a harmonious balance with its tropical setting. A separate guest pavilion feels like part of the hillside, composed of green Indian stone and bengkerai wood. The roof is artistically altered to incorporate the entrance. The home embodies the owners' desire for space and seclusion, offering a tranquil retreat that stays in harmony with Balinese aesthetics and the beauty of the natural environment.

parts.title: Modernist Coastal Home with Nature-Integrated Design
parts.body: In modern home designs, Alessandro Landi combines an open-plan living concept with dramatic floor-to-ceiling glazing that enhances spectacular coastal views. The sleek design is balanced with raw elements like granite and bamboo flooring. Architects like Richard Neutra inspire the home to mediate man and nature, promoting modern living concepts of sun, space, and greenery. Though located in Bali, the house stands out with international charm rather than traditional Indonesian styles. Inside, this modern utopia remains consistent with its exterior, utilizing grey tones highlighted by chromatic red accents such as a bright red chaise longue. A minimalist garden and a narrow lap pool lined with green sukabumi stone frame the home, embodying an exercise in restraint yet designed for maximum aesthetic impact. Textures like Indian slate and volcanic stone complement the clean architectural lines, while subtle lighting brings out textural intricacies during the night. Art from Just Jen’s, casually placed within the living space, offers a subtle nod to Indonesian culture while maintaining overall modernist appeal.

parts.title: Design and Architecture of Tra Villa in Canggu
parts.body: This villa in Canggu was built between 2006 and 2007, designed by Yoka Sara of Bale Legend. The owners initially weren't attracted to Bali due to its commercialization. However, they eventually fell in love with the jungle and rice fields, which inspired the design of their home. Their vision was to always feel like they were outside in these natural settings. The villa's architecture features hollow steel, composite aluminum, and glass, giving it both a modern and a natural touch. Ironwood columns, used in the structure, add to its character. The villa's design integrates with its surroundings, with views extending towards a river and rice fields. The landscape design also contributes to this integration, using local plants such as banana trees and slim palms to enhance their tropical living environment.

parts.title: Surfer's Dream Retreat in Bali
parts.body: This retreat in Bali was built for a dedicated surfer with spectacular ocean views over Padang Padang and Suluban. Designed by David Lombardi, the house blends indoor-outdoor living and ensures easy wave access. A main structure with shingled roof and lighter bedroom volumes incorporates a carport and perforated copper entrance door, showcasing local craftsmanship. The spacious living area with cooling materials like palimanan stone and terrazzo floors looks out to a minimalist landscaped garden and pool, enhancing relaxation for any surfer.

parts.title: The Calyx Boutique Resort Review
parts.body: LEFT: The master bedroom from one of the four villas at The Calyx showcases a sloping wooden roof and glazed windows offering ocean views. An impressive glass sculpture by Seiki Torige adds an artistic touch. The resort's communal pool extends over the Indian ocean; nearby, an open bar and lounge offer sweeping vistas, adding to the serene atmosphere. The Calyx, named after a plant's supporting part, offers a unique retreat. Designed by Gfab, the boutique resort prioritizes energy efficiency and blends into its landscape. The cream sandstone walls, flat plant-covered roofs, and strategic room placements maximize natural cooling and relaxation, creating a sequestered and modern ambience.

parts.title: Tirtha Wedding Chapels in Bali
parts.body: The Tirtha wedding chapels in Bali offer a stunning backdrop for weddings. These chapels sit on a cliff with breathtaking views over the Indian Ocean. Designed by a Japanese entrepreneur and architect Glenn Parker, Tirtha Uluwatu and Tirtha Luhur combine traditional and modern elements. The design concept includes ivory palimanan stone and an A-line chapel with glass panels and a Teflon roof, giving a sense of lightness and romance. The architect aimed to create a dramatic, yet culturally relevant design that reflects Bali's vernacular architecture.

parts.title: Bamboo House Integration
parts.body: Bamboo House: This villa, built for Italian businessman Kiko A Croserio, uniquely uses bamboo in its construction, giving it a rustic vibe. The house is a testament to blending traditional Indonesian materials with modern architecture. Bamboo is used for poles and beams, alongside clay and wood, creating a home integrated with nature. Perched on a tranquil site near Tanah Lot, the villa boasts an open-plan layout with a free-form swimming pool and views of the ocean. Wolfgang Widmoser assisted in its design, influenced by Indonesian tradition and the legendary Frei Otto. A distinct feature is the house's bamboo support, thatched roof, and integration of indoor and outdoor elements, providing a seamless flow for relaxed living.
